sub_topic: Finding the area under a curve using integration
message_1: Find the area enclosed between the x-axis, x = 2 and x = 5 by the curve y = 3x - 1 using integration.
message_2:
To find the area enclosed between the x-axis, x = 2 and x = 5 by the curve y = 3x - 1, we will use the definite integral. The definite integral represents the signed area between the curve and the x-axis.

The area A can be found using the formula:

A = ∫[a, b] (f(x) dx)

where f(x) is the function y = 3x - 1, a = 2, and b = 5.

A = ∫[2, 5] (3x - 1) dx

To find the integral, we will first find the antiderivative of the function (3x - 1).

The antiderivative of (3x - 1) is:

F(x) = (3/2)x^2 - x + C

Now, we will evaluate the definite integral:

A = F(5) - F(2)

A = [(3/2)(5)^2 - (5)] - [(3/2)(2)^2 - (2)]

A = [(3/2)(25) - 5] - [(3/2)(4) - 2]

A = [37.5 - 5] - [6 - 2]

A = [32.5] - [4]

A = 28.5

The area enclosed between the x-axis, x = 2 and x = 5 by the curve y = 3x - 1 is 28.5 square units.
